events.event_name: S&P Global UK Services PMI Release (January)
events.description: The UK Services PMI was released for January, showing a rise to 54 from 51.4 in December.

facts.fact_text: The S&P Global UK Services PMI rose to 54 in January from 51.4 in December.

evidences.evidence_text: The S&P Global UK Services PMI rose to 54 in January from 51.4 in December, below preliminary estimates of 54.3 but still the highest since August 2025.

facts.fact_text: Staffing levels in the UK services sector have fallen for four consecutive months.

evidences.evidence_text: staffing levels falling for a fourth straight month and marking the longest period of job losses in 16 years

facts.fact_text: Input costs for service firms rose due to higher payroll, technology, and raw material costs.

evidences.evidence_text: Input costs rose sharply, driven mainly by higher payroll, technology and raw material costs

claims.claim_text: New business growth was supported by higher client spending and investment in new technologies.
claims.author: S&P Global

evidences.evidence_text: New business grew at a solid pace and reached a 3-month high, supported by higher client spending, digital marketing budgets and investment in new technologies

claims.claim_text: Job losses are a result of firms focusing on cost control and automation.
claims.author: S&P Global

evidences.evidence_text: staffing levels falling... as firms focused on cost control and automation

claims.claim_text: Business optimism has reached its highest level since October 2024 despite cost concerns.
claims.author: S&P Global

evidences.evidence_text: Business optimism improved to the highest since October 2024, although concerns about costs and long-term growth persisted

evidence.evidence_text: The S&P Global UK Services PMI rose to 54 in January... still the highest since August 2025.
Input costs rose sharply... prompting the steepest increase in prices charged since August 2025.
staffing levels falling for a fourth straight month... as firms focused on cost control and automation.
subdued household demand and weak construction activity weighed on some sectors.
